newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Stena Line says wants to work with P&O.
newsitem.headline: Stena Line says wants to work with P&O.

text.p: Swedish ferry company Stena Line wants to cooperate with British ferry operator the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Co (P&O), Stena Managing Director Bo Lerenius said on Monday.
"No contact has yet been made but I suppose that we will start discussions with P&O within three to four weeks," Lerenius told Reuters.
"With the day's tough price situation some form of cooperation is desirable."
Lerenius said the type of cooperation between the two companies was not certain and he declined to elaborate further.
Cooperation between the two companies has been made possible as British authorities recently lifted a ban on cross-Channel ferry operators working together.

Lerenius said the precarious situation for the shipping industry began when Eurotunnel halved its prices before the summer's peak season. Eurotunnel has posed a serious challenge to ferry operators on the Dover-Calais route since its opening in late 1994.

"We were very surprised by this but had no other choice other than to lower our prices as well," Lerenius said. "Now we first and foremost want to have some kind of cooperation with P&O that will bring down costs and give up better results.
"We also want price levels to become more stable."
Lerenius said he was not surprised that the Eurotunnel more than doubled traffic on Le Shuttle, the Eurotunnel's train operating between England and France.
Traffic increased to 304,032 vehicles in August this year from 145,861 vehicles in 1995.
"We have also increased volumes steadily this year," he said. "The problem now instead is the higher costs."
